instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message:
Hello.

Mac <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> doesnt turns on.
3 of 4 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> rebooting, LDO 1.1 present.
UB400 steady 5V, 0Amps, no LDO 1.1v After changing UB400 no changes.
Found out that all PPBUS lines are missing (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> )
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>  - 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3
Diode mode for ppbus lines is 0.4
Diode mode for all LDOs of UB400 matches other <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>
Changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - no changes.
Since there are no short on ppbus i've tried to inject 13 volts to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. With injected voltage - 3 <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> switching to 20 volts and rebooting, UB400 is not reacting for charger at all. USB-C meter doesn't turns on.
Checked the board with thermal cam - nothing gets hot. But looks like there is a short circuit somewhere...How can i find it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message:
You have to fix the problem on UB400 area first.
Other things around the chip affected; if the new chip is good 100%.

I recommend to try another <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> first.
Once removed, check the traces for its pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message: <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is good 100%. Checked it on another board. Also traces is ok, checked each trace under UB400

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message:
Change QB400.
Check all resistors and small coils related with UB400.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message:
I found the problem, but it's a little weird...
I decided to check all the pins under UB400 in diode mode, and found out that pin 36 ( <SIGNAL>UPC_TA_UART_RX</SIGNAL> ) has very low resistance, just 26 Ohm. This pin goes to resistor RB305, and it should be 1 MOhm. I removed RB305, puted back UB400 and mac works.
   What is weird - i thought when resistor goes bad - resistance can only get higher value, not less. Is it possible that 1M resistor became 26 Ohm?
Or RB is not a resistor?
And one more question: is it necessary to solder back new RB305, or i can just remove it and forget about it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
threads.message:
Corrosion on a resistor can easy drop down its ohm value; especially for high ohm resistors.
Is like connecting another (parasite) resistor in parallel with it.

You should put back new 1M resistor.
I think UB400 boots from UB300, through <SIGNAL>UPC_TA_UART_RX</SIGNAL>/TX lines.
UB300 boots first from UB090.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0 Amps
